review.title: Modeling Curiosity in a Mobile Robot for Long-Term Autonomous Exploration and Monitoring
review.abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to modeling curiosity in a mobile robot, which is useful for monitoring and adaptive data collection tasks, especially in the context of long term autonomous missions where pre-programmed missions are likely to have limited utility. We use a realtime topic modeling technique to build a semantic perception model of the environment, using which, we plan a path through the locations in the world with high semantic information content. The life-long learning behavior of the proposed perception model makes it suitable for long-term exploration missions. We validate the approach using simulated exploration experiments using aerial and underwater data, and demonstrate an implementation on the Aqua underwater robot in a variety of scenarios. We find that the proposed exploration paths that are biased towards locations with high topic perplexity, produce better terrain models with high discriminative power. Moreover, we show that the proposed algorithm implemented on Aqua robot is able to do tasks such as coral reef inspection, diver following, and sea floor exploration, without any prior training or preparation.

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Results
sections.text: The results are both encouraging and surprising. As shown in Figure 5 and6, we see that the topic of perplexity-based exploration (shown with blue squares) is consistently better than any other weight function when compared with the truth of the ground or the robot outcomes. For paths of length 80, which is close to the width of the maps, we see that the mutual information between thematic perplexity-based exploration and the truth of the ground is 1.51, 1.20 and 1.05 times higher than the topic of the robot, compared with the next-best execution technique. For long paths (320 steps or more), stochastic reporting (shown with orange circles) based exploration coincides with the mean performance of thematic perplexity exploration. This is expected because the maps are limited, and as the path length increases, the stochastic coverage algorithm is able to trip over different terrains without even having a guide function.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Scenario 1: Exploring a coral head
sections.text: In this experiment, we started the robot near a coral head surrounded by monotonous sand. We see that the robot is quickly attracted to the coral head and continues to hop over this structure while staying away from the sand. We see the effect of curiosity decay variable γ, as the robot is successfully able to return to the coral head several times after crossing the much less interesting sand regions.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Scenario 2: Interaction with a diver
sections.text: Although our goal was to study the robot as it would interact with a fish, due to a lack of cooperation with the fish, we were forced to conduct the experiment with a diver instead. We see that once it is in the sight of the robot, it is the only source of curiosity for the robot. We see the robot follow the diver and hover over the diver when it has stopped moving.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Scenario 3: Exploring the ocean floor
sections.text: In this experiment, we started the robot near the seabed, which was sparsely populated with marine plants and corals. We see that the robot manages to focus on marine life without wasting time on sand.

sections.heading: 6 Summary
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a long-term exploration technology that aims to learn an observation model of the world by finding pathways with high information content. Using a framework for real-time, lifelong learning and thematic modeling allows us to describe the incoming streams of low-threshold observation data by using latent variables that represent the terrain type. Considering this online lifelong learning model, we calculate the benefit of the potential next steps on the path in terms of their perplexity. In our underwater video demonstration, we see that the emerging behavior of the robot bears a striking resemblance to that of biological organisms by calculating mutual information between the terrain maps generated by using the learned terrain model, and hand-signing the ground truth on three different datasets.
